Investigators have been looking into last month's deadly Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia.
They say it could have been prevented by a safety system called positive train control, which can slow or stop a train.
Freight and passenger railroads are struggling to meet a federal deadline to fully implement it by the end of the year.
Amtrak says it will meet the deadline in the busy Northeast Corridor, but most commuter railroads, which carried passengers on 500 million rides last year, won't.
Here's NPR's David Schaper.
I'm standing in the Metra rail yard on the southern edge of Downtown Chicago.
There are a few dozen commuter trains here idling as they prepare to take thousands of people from their jobs downtown to their homes in city neighborhoods and suburbs near and far.
Behind me is a nondescript, two-story brick building that houses the control center for these rail lines and the brains of what will be Metra's positive train control system.
Out of this building, we control the Metra Electric District, the Rock Island.
Running down the list of Chicago-area commuter rail lines that he oversees here is chief dispatcher Sal Cuevas.
Over 300 and 350, maybe 400 trains out of this facility that we control.
That's only about half of the commuter trains Metra moves into and out of the city each day.
Cuevas is tracking their movement, their speed and any potential problems in coordination with the 500 freight trains moving through Chicago.
Positive train control won't make his job any easier, but Cuevas says it will make those trains safer.
Integrating their system with our current train control system will hopefully minimize incidents.
Positive train control, or PTC, integrates computer, satellite and radio technologies to slow down or stop a train if the engineer becomes incapacitated, misses a signal or is going too fast.
But the complex safety system won't be fully implemented for some time.
Metra's executive director Don Orseno says Chicago's commuter trains won't make the 2015 deadline set by Congress, and it won't even be close.
Our expectation for Metra to be fully operational is in 2019.
Why is it taking so long?
There's a lot of reasons why it's taking so long.
Number one, it wasn't invented.
Orseno says the railroads had to develop the complicated system from scratch.
PTC has to download information about track conditions, speed limits, the length and weight of trains and other data.
Computers in the control centers and in the locomotives must communicate with every track signal and every other train.
It requires new signals, new radios, computer hardware and software to interface with all of the other railroads and all of their equipment.
In Chicago, the nation's busiest rail hub, that's 1,300 freight and passenger trains a day.
We operate the most complex system in the country.
There's no question about that.
And Orseno says in mandating positive train control by the end of this year, Congress provided almost no funding.
We're looking anywhere from about $350 million for this system.
And you're talking about commuter rail service.
There's not that kind of money out there.
And it's not just Metra, but most commuter rail agencies around the country will need another three to five years to implement positive train control.
Michael Melaniphy, president of the American Public Transportation Association, says they simply lack the resources to do it.
And he's not just talking money.
There's only so many people that are experts in this area.
We can only produce so many of the radio sets that are needed and the spectrum that's needed to run those radios in a given time.
Melaniphy says acquiring that radio spectrum for PTC has been especially difficult for commuter railroads.
Many of the operators will be able to obtain it in some segments but maybe not along the entire corridor.
They have to figure out who owns the spectrum in a given corridor and negotiate with them to either sell it or lease it.

Melaniphy is hoping Congress will allow the FCC to provide commuter railroads with the radio spectrum they need for free and will extend the deadline for commuter and freight railroads to implement a safety system that all agree is needed.
David Schaper, NPR News, Chicago.
The legacy of Oscar Romero is strongly linked to liberation theology, a left-leaning view of the church's role in society.
For more on that controversial movement, we spoke to Boston Globe religion editor, John Allen, who traveled to San Salvador for the beatification.

Liberation theology was a movement in Catholic thought that arose in Latin America in the late '50s, early '60s and was basically born by a group of Catholic thinkers who were looking at the social reality of Latin America, which, at the time, was defined largely by crushing poverty and the domination of both wealth and political power by a very thin veneer of social elites, and who drew the conclusion that that was not the gospel vision of how life ought to work.
And so they began pressing the Catholic Church to stand on the side of the poor.
It became a very controversial movement.

It also became controversial in the Vatican, where there was concerns that it was overly given to relying on Marxist analysis in that it ended up blessing violence, and so titanic battles were fought.
And so the kind of rehabilitation that has been going on under Pope Francis, all of that has been seen widely in the church as healing old wounds.
Those old wounds in El Salvador, especially, have to do with Archbishop Romero and his assassination.
You have called him a hero of the liberation theology movement.
Would you call him a follower of that movement?
Okay, thanks a lot.
No.
I think he was someone who tried to transcend the division between the liberation theology crowd and the more traditional, spiritual crowd.

However, as the symbol of Romero has played out in the 35 years since his death, I think it is fair to say that Archbishop Romero is seen as a great hero and an icon by the progressive, socially involved wing of the Catholic Church and yet, to this day, is seen with some ambivalence by the more conservative wing of the Church.
And what about Pope Francis?
He is not, I would say, an advocate of liberation theology exactly, but he has definitely made a turn from his predecessor, Pope Benedict.
You're right to say that Pope Francis is not himself, and nor has he ever been, identified as a liberation theologian.
In fact, back in the 1970s when he was the leader of the Jesuit order in Argentina, he was sometimes seen as an enemy of liberation theology.

But on the other hand, I think what this beatification, in Pope Francis's mind - what it says is that the main thrust of what Romero stood for and the main thrust of what the liberation theologians stood for, which is the quest of the poor for justice, was right, and he wants it to be the official policy of the Universal Catholic Church in his time.
